discussion.content:
"Bench Stock means those expendable or consumable items routinely replaced during inspection, repair or maintenance."
This was a new phrase for me.

questions.question_text:
Following a recent outage, a systems administrator is conducting a study to determine a suitable bench stock on server hard drives.
Which of the following metrics is MOST valuable to the administrator in determining how many hard drives to keep-on hand?

discussion.content:
Maintain privacy of students in case of loss - Full Disk Encryption 
Have a theft detection control in place - GeoFencing

Maybe: A. Remote wiping ? 
"Maintain privacy of students in case of loss"

questions.question_text:
A school contracts with a vendor to devise a solution that will enable the school library to lend out tablet computers to students while on site. The tablets must adhere to string security and privacy practices. The school's key requirements are to:
✑ Maintain privacy of students in case of loss
✑ Have a theft detection control in place
✑ Be compliant with defined disability requirements
Have a four-hour minimum battery life
//IMG//

Which of the following should be configured to BEST meet the requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: SRTM is the "Security Requirements Traceability Matrix" but the question does not mention anything about security. Still, probably the best answer there is.

questions.question_text:
A project manager is working with a software development group to collect and evaluate user scenarios related to the organization's internally designed data analytics tool. While reviewing stakeholder input, the project manager would like to formally document the needs of the various stakeholders and the associated organizational compliance objectives supported by the project.
Which of the following would be MOST appropriate to use?

discussion.content: Actually this question may be pointing you towards diagnosing if there was a data spill, which would lend toward A. So I'm really not sure. A is definitely a candidate.

comments.content: You make a good point. No doubt, the system will be wiped, so who cares if it's rooted? The most urgent priority is to find out if there was a data spill.

discussion.content:
C
I would definitely go with C. If TPM is active you shouldn't be able to boot a rooted system. Check your FS Binaries and scan the hard disk. Realistically, you'd just recover any data that was vital and reimage the laptop anyway, but that isn't an option here. Can't imagine scanning for UEFI vulnerabilities AFTER a device went missing--you should validate UEFI and TPM before the device is issued out for service.

Maybe: C. File system integrity?
Seems like, at least, as good an answer. Certainly the system might have been rooted.

questions.question_text:
A laptop is recovered a few days after it was stolen.
Which of the following should be verified during incident response activities to determine the possible impact of the incident?

choices.B: It is not blocking or filtering any traffic to the server.
choices.A: It is correctly dropping all packets destined for the server.
choices.D: The IDS functionality of the firewall is currently disabled.

discussion.content: The best ansuer is A, but according with this https://www.coresentinel.com/reject-versus-drop/ and this https://community.spiceworks.com/topic/1990755-deny-traffic-vs-drop-traffic the good answer should be the word reject insted of drop.
